questions.text: Mr Mehta, 50 years male developed an intolerable pain in his left loin, the pain was radiating to his testicles. He is shouting of severe pain. He was shifted to casualty. What is the IOC to diagnose the pathology
questions.solution:
• On account of the fact that other serious pathology can be wrongly attributed to a urinary tract stone, the diagnosis of a urinary tract calculus needs to be confirmed at the earliest opportunity with a non-contrast CT scan.
  • A supplementary plain x-ray is often performed to assess if the stone(s) are radio-opaque and if plain x-rays can be used in the follow-up of a patient who is expected to pass a stone spontaneously

Dipstick Hematuria+

  • Visible haematuria is rarely present but dipstick haematuria is a frequent accompaniment to the pain, such that if a patient does not have detectable dipstick haematuria other diagnoses need to be seriously considered this is especially true in the elderly male presenting for the first time with pain suggestive of a urinary tract stone, in whom a leaking abdominal aortic aneurysm should always be considered and discounted

(Ref Bailey and Love Page 1408, 27th Edition)

choices.text: More than one session of ESWL may be needed
Prophylactic antibiotics may not be needed in non obstructive cases
Cystine stones are difficult to break
Stein strasse is a complication in this case

questions.text: Mr Gupta 50 years male was diagnosed to have a stone in his right kidney of size 12 mm. He had history of ureteric colicky due to ureteric stone which passed away few weeks back. He is planned for ESWL. Which is false regarding this treatment?
questions.solution:
• Indicated for stones upto 1.5 cm in size
  • More than one treatment session may be needed
  • Prophylactic antibiotics are used to prevent infection as stones are often colonised by bacteria.
  • Cystine stones are relatively resistant to ESWL due to their hardness.
  • Complications- Infection, haematuria, parenchymal haemorrhage and even perirenal haematoma.
  • Steinstrasse (‘street of stones’)is an interesting complication which might have been prevented by stenting,.
  • Contraindications to ESWL are obese patients, pregnant patients and patients taking oral anticoagulants.

Ref. Bailey and Love 27th Edition Page 1408

Steinstrasse

questions.text: Mr Kumar, 10 years old boy presented with hydronephrosis on USG. The Best investigation to diagnose the Obstructive dilatation of collecting system is shown below: What is this investigation?
questions.solution:
• Isotope renography is the best test to confirm obstructive dilatation of the collecting system.
  • A substance (usually diethylenetriaminepentaacetic acid (DTPA) or MAG-3) is injected intravenously.
  • The DTPA is labelled with technetium- 99m, a gamma-ray emitter, so that the passage of 99mTc-labelled DTPA through the kidneys can be tracked using a gamma camera.
  • 99mTc-DTPA is cleared from a normal kidney but stays in the renal pelvis on the obstructed side and is retained even if urine flow is increased by administering frusemide
  • Very occasionally, a Whitaker test is indicated. A percutaneous puncture of the kidney is made and fluid is infused at a constant rate with monitoring of intrapelvic pressure.
  • An abnormal rise in pressure confirms obstruction.

Ref. Bailey 27th Edition page 1412

choices.text: Laceration extends to renal pelvis with extravasation of urine

questions.text: Mr Ramu 40 years male underwent Road traffic accident and presented with hematuria. He is found to have Renal injury on CECT scan. The finding to say the patient is having Grade 4 renal injury is:
questions.solution:
Grade IV:

  • Laceration extends to renal pelvis or urinary extravasation.
  • Vascular: injury to main renal artery or vein with contained haemorrhage.
  • Segmental infarctions without associated lacerations.
  • Expanding subcapsular haematomas compressing the kidney.

Ref. Bailey Page 1413, 27th edition

questions.text: A new born baby presents with below findings. The following are the associated features seen in this disease Except
questions.solution:
• Bladder exstrophy occurs in 1:50 000 births (male:female ratio 4:1)
  • In males, the penis is broad and short, and bilateral inguinal herniae may be present.
  • There is separation of the pubic bones
  • In epispadias alone, the pubes are united and external genitalia are almost normal, although in females the clitoris is bifid

Ref. Bailey 27th Edition page 1424

questions.text: Mr. Ramu, 69 years male presented with severe claudication pain in both side calf, thigh and Buttock. On further history he is having sexual problems also. He is unable to walk even for 50 metres continuously and he takes rest before he restarts to walk. On examination the Pulses are feeble in Both side Femoral arteries. Both Popliteal and Anterior tibial arteries are absent. What is the correct answer regarding this patient?
questions.solution:
Aorto Iliac occlusion - features:

  • Buttock claudication
  • Impotence
  • Bilateral Thigh and Calf Claudication

The patient here comes under Boyd Classification- Grade 3

questions.text: As per Crawford Classification- the image of the aneurysm shown here is?
questions.solution:
Crawford Classification of Thoraco Abdominal Aneurysm



Type I- Left SCA to Renal Artery level

Type II- Left SCA to Bifurcation – Most largest**

Type III- Mid Descending aorta to Bifurcation

Type IV- Upper abdominal aorta and all or none of Infra renal artery

questions.text: False statement regarding RFA treatment for Varicose veins
False statement of MILROY's Disease
The Surgery for Lymphedema- Pick the wrong match
questions.solution:
• Charles – whole subcutaneous and skin excised up to deep fascia and SSG done
  • Sistrunk - wedge excision of skin and subcutaneous tissue and wound closed primarily.
  • Thompson – buried Dermal flap. Common complication of this procedure is Pilonidal sinus
  • Homans – skin flap raised, subcutaneous tissue removed.
    • Most satisfactory operation.
    • Main complication is skin flap necrosis
    • Contraindicated in presence of venous obstruction and malignancy

questions.text: T3 Lung cancer means all except
questions.solution:
( Size 5-7cm, Invades 3P- Parietal pleura, Phrenic Nerve, Parietal pericardium)

TNM Staging

  • T1- Tumor < 3cm size; Not involves beyond the lobar bronchus ( But not Main Bronchus)
    • T1a- upto 1cm
    • T1b- 1 to < 2 cm
    • T1c- 2 to < 3 cm

 

  • T2- Tumor >3cm but < 5cm
    • Involves main bronchus ( But not carina)
    • Involves Pleura ( only visceral pleura)
    • Atelectasis+
    • Obstructive pneumonitis+
  • T3- Tumor >5cm upto < 7cm lesion
    • Directly invades Chest wall
    • Parietal pleura
    • Phrenic nerve
    • Parietal Pericardium

 

  • T4- Tumor size > 7cm size
    • Separate tumor nodules in a ipsilateral lobe.
    • Infiltration to diaphragm, esophagus, heart, trachea, RLN, Vertebral body and carina

Thoracoscore

  • The Thoracoscore is the most widely used model to assess risk of operative mortality in thoracic patients.
  • It is currently the most robust model available to estimate the risk of death when considering patients for thoracic surgery.

Nine variables

Mnemonic- ASAP- Plan Doctor’s CME

  • Age,
  • Sex,
  • American Society of Anesthesiologists (ASA) score,
  • Performance status,
  • Priority of surgery,
  • Dyspnoea score,
  • Composite comorbidity score.
  • Malignant diagnosis
  • Extent of surgery,

questions.text: Regarding Breast reduction mammoplasty - false statement is
questions.solution:
Principles of Breast reduction

  • To decrease the volume of the breast
  • To reshape the breast to correct ptosis,
  • To elevate the breast tissue to an anatomically correct position on the chest wall,
  • To reposition the nipple and areola on the reduced and reshaped breast,
  • To preserve the nerve supply to the skin and nipple-areola complex,
  • To maintain blood supply to the breast tissue,
  • To minimize scars.

Inferior Pedicle Technique



Pre requisites

  • All patients >35 years must undergo Mammography to rule out cancer
  • The removed Breast tissue must be sent for HPE.
  • No set lower age limit for this surgery
  • In adolescents we must do reduction only when the breast stops growing for at least 12 months.
  • 2nd Time Breast Reduction is not done due to risk of loss of blood supply to breast.
  • Irradiated Breast patients are delayed for Mammoplasty
  • Smoking is a contraindication for Breast Reduction.
  • Obese patients has high complication rates.

Complications

  • Lactation and Breast feeding are not possible.
  • Changes in Nipple sensation ( More of increased sensation than decreased sensation)
  • Wound dehiscence, skin slough, loss of tissue, hematoma, infection, and fat necrosis.

questions.text:
Regarding CAD
Assertion: Surgery is indicated when a carotid artery is completely occluded
Reason: Due to severe recurrent symptoms in all patients after complete occlusion
questions.solution: Surgery is generally not indicated when carotid artery is known to be completely occluded because the surgical risk for performing a thrombectomy of a chronically occluded ICA is high. Additionally, most patients do not experience recurrent symptoms after has become completely occluded because embolization is unlikely to occur once the stream of blood flow over the plaque has ceased.

questions.text: For reimplantation surgery, the detached digit or limp is best preserved in
questions.solution: The amputated part is cleaned with a sterile isotonic solution, wrapped in moist sterile gauze. It should be then sealed in waterproof bag. This bag are now placed in container of ice and sent to the reimplantation center. Note: Permissible ischemic time is maximum 8 hours for proximal amputation where as 12 hours for the digits.

questions.text: Which anatomic location is the most common site of extra-adrenal pheochromocytomas?
questions.solution: Pheochromocytomas arise from neuroectodermal cells and are most often found within the adrenal medulla. Ten percent of all pheochromocytomas are located outside of the adrenal gland along the embryologic path of the adrenal gland. The most common site of an extra adrenal pheochromocytoma is in the paraaortic area.

questions.text: The intense pain associated with a felon occurs because of
questions.solution: A felon is an infection of the distal pulp space of a digit, usually secondary to a puncture wound. This is a closed space at the level of the distal interphalangeal joint. Since the infection cannot spread proximal to this point, pain is throbbing and intense. Late osteomyelitis may develop in the distal phalanx if the felon is not opened appropriately.

questions.text: When a patient is seen with a slab wound of the neck that has injured the left vertebral artery, the most frequent clinical finding is
questions.solution: With the injury described, neurologic findings are very rare and gross hemorrhagic shock is unusual. A stable hematoma is the most common presentation

questions.text: A 24 year old man is brought into the emergency department after a fall from a ladder. His breathing is labored and he is cyanotic. No breath sounds can be heard even in the right lung field, which is resonant to percussion. The first step in his management should be
questions.solution: This patient has a tension pneumothorax and immediate management by needle thoracotomy is imperative. This diagnosis is a clinical one and treatment should not await x - ray confirmation. After some of the pneomothorax has been relieved, then we may go for tube thoracostomy

questions.text: After renal transplantation which of the following cancer is very common?
questions.solution: The most common lesions are cancer of the skin and lips and carcinoma in situ of the cervix, as well as lymphomas such as non-Hodgkin's lymphoma.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for a 32- year -old male with a toxic nodular goiter and compressive airway symptoms?
questions.solution:
Therapy with antithyroid medications or beta blocker may help alleviate symptoms but is not definitive, especially if the patient possesses local symptoms of compression. Radioiodine therapy is not effective  as in Grave's disease because of lower uptake.

I131 ablation may be used in patients who are unsuitable for surgery but because of the high failure rate, local resection is considered the treatment of choice. For solitary nodules, nodulectomy or thyroid lobectomy is the treatment of choice. For solitary nodules nodulectomy or thyroid lobectomy is the treatment of choice.

Transitional cell carcinoma is most common carcinoma of bladder.

Occupations with a risk of carcinoma bladder,

  • Schistosoma haematobium infestation (Bilharziasis) is associated with squamous cell carcinoma of urinary bladder.

questions.text: Which of the following is common in extramedullary intradural location?
questions.solution:
Intradural, extramedullary tumours

It is found within the dura but outside the substance of spinal cord.

Most tumours are benign

Common tumours are:

Meningioma

Schwannoma

Neurofibroma

Most common primary spinal tumor

-Nerve sheath tumor

Most common extradural tumor - Metastasis

Most common intramedullary tumor:Ependymoma

questions.text: Which of the following requires emergency operation in setting without tertiary care facilities?
questions.solution: Extradural hematoma is a surgical emergency. The death will occur if not removed early. Therefore it can be removed even in small set up without any tertiary care facilities.

questions.text: A lady presents with galactorrhea and visual defects. First investigation of choice
questions.solution:
1. MRI is the imaging of choice for pituitary tumour. It is preferred over CT scan.
  2. Here the galactorrhea with visual defect represent pituitary tumour i.e. prolactinoma. Thus first investigation is MRI but serum prolactin should also be measured.
  3. Level more than 200ng/ml is diagnostic of prolactinoma

questions.text: The commonest space occupying lesion (S.O.L.) in the cerebellopontine angle is
questions.solution:
Common tumours of CP (cerebellopontine) angle are

  1. Acoustic neuroma (commonest: 80-90%)
  2. Meningioma (2nd commonest: 5-10%)

Since acoustic neuroma is not in option next common is meningioma.

questions.text: Radiological sign of raised intracranial tension in a child is
questions.solution:
Radiological sign of raised intracranial tension is

  1. Sutural separation (diastasis)
  2. Copper beating marking of the cranial vault
  3. Thinning of the dorsum sellae
  4. Erosion of posterior clinoid processes.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of stauffer syndrome?
questions.solution: Stauffer syndrome is a constellation of signs and symptoms of liver dysfunction that arise due to presence of renal cell carcinoma but are not due to tumour infiltration into the liver and/or intrinsic liver disease; it is a paraneoplastic syndrome.

questions.text: Young man with a UTI should be treated with antibiotics for:
questions.solution: Bacterial UTI in women should be treated with 3 days of antibiotics. In men, bacterial UTI should be treated with 7 days, of antibiotics and younger men should be evaluated for correctable structure anomalies with an IVU or CT scan with IV contrast and a cystoscopy.

questions.text: Treatment of medullary carcinoma thyroid
questions.solution:
Total thyroidectomy is the treatment of choice for patients with MTC because of the high incidence of multicentricity, the more aggressive course and 131 I therapy is not usually effective.

The central compartment nodes are frequently involved early in the disease process, so that a bilateral central neck node dissection should be routinely performed.

In patients with palpable cervical nodes or involved central neck nodes ipsilateral or bilateral modified radical neck dissection is recommended.

choices.text: It is difficult to differentiate it from anaplastic carcinoma
If it involves the isthmus it may present with respiratory insufficiency.

questions.text: All of the following statements are true regarding Thyroid lymphoma except:
questions.solution:
About thyroid lymphoma:

  • Often arises in back ground of Hashimoto's thyroiditis.
  • Presents as rapidly enlarging thyroid mass
  • MC type- diffuse large cell variant
  • Histology shows: sheets of lymphoid cells
  • Histological difficult to distinguish from small cell lung cancer

questions.text: Paraplegia after operative repair of coarctation of the aorta is usually caused by:
questions.solution: Paraplegia is an infrequent but disastrous complication of the operation. It is usually caused by aortic cross clamping and is associated with a fall in distal aortic pressure. When a long cross- clamping period (greater than 20 to 30min) or a drop in distal aortic pressure below 50 to 60 mmHg is anticipated, the use of an intra operative shunt may prevent this problem.
